title: Your First Sentences
goal: Build simple Lojban sentences using pronouns and gismu.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Rapid-fire pronunciation review from Day 1. Say each word aloud, stressing the first syllable:

Lojban → English (cover the right side, test yourself)
prami  → love (x1 loves x2)
klama  → go (x1 goes to x2...)
tavla  → talk (x1 talks to x2...)

Now say these consonant sounds three times each:

  • c = "sh" (as in citka)
  • x = "kh" (as in xamgu)
  • . = pause (a tiny silence before vowels)

New Material (5-7 min)

The Bridi — Lojban's Core Sentence

mi tavla do — I talk to you.

That's a complete Lojban sentence. Three words, no conjugation, no tense, no articles. Here's what just happened:

The word tavla is the selbri (the relationship — "talking"). The words mi and do are sumti (the participants — "I" and "you"). Together, a selbri and its sumti form a bridi (a claim about the world).

Every Lojban sentence is a bridi. Every bridi has this shape:

[sumti] selbri [sumti] [sumti] ...
   x1            x2      x3

The first sumti before the selbri fills the x1 slot. Sumti after the selbri fill x2, x3, and so on, left to right.

Three Pronouns

Lojban English Notes
mi I, me the speaker
do you the listener
ti this (here) something near the speaker

These are cmavo — short grammar words (1-2 syllables). You'll learn dozens of cmavo over the coming weeks. Pronouns are the first batch.

Building Simple Bridi

Put mi in x1, a gismu as the selbri, and you have a sentence:

Lojban Gloss English
mi prami I love I love (someone).
mi klama I go I go (somewhere).
mi tavla I talk I talk (to someone).
mi citka I eat I eat (something).
mi pinxe I drink I drink (something).

The missing sumti (x2, x3...) are simply left unsaid. In Lojban, if you don't fill a place, it's understood as "unspecified" — not missing, just unstated.

Adding a Second Sumti

Now put do in x2:

Lojban Gloss English
mi prami do I love you I love you.
mi tavla do I talk-to you I talk to you.

Or use ti for something nearby:

Lojban Gloss English
mi citka ti I eat this I eat this.
mi pinxe ti I drink this I drink this.

Key Point

A bridi (sentence) = selbri (relationship) + sumti (participants). Put a sumti before the selbri for x1, and after for x2, x3, etc.

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Translation (Lojban → English)

Translate to English:

  1. mi klama
  2. mi prami do
  3. mi citka ti
  4. mi pinxe
  5. do tavla mi
Answers
  1. I go.
  2. I love you.
  3. I eat this.
  4. I drink.
  5. You talk to me.

Exercise 2: Fill the Blank

Fill in the missing word:

  1. ___ prami do (I love you) → ?
  2. mi ___ do (I talk to you) → ?
  3. mi citka ___ (I eat this) → ?
  4. ___ klama (You go) → ?
  5. mi ___ ti (I drink this) → ?
Answers
  1. mi
  2. tavla
  3. ti
  4. do
  5. pinxe

Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud in Lojban:

  1. "I eat."
  2. "I talk to you."
  3. "You love me."

Answer key:

  1. mi citka
  2. mi tavla do
  3. do prami mi

Today's Vocab

Lojban Place Structure English
citka x1 eats x2 eat
pinxe x1 drinks x2 drink
cadzu x1 walks on x2 walk

Cmavo introduced today:

Lojban Function English
mi pronoun I, me
do pronoun you
ti pronoun this (near speaker)

Terms introduced today:

Term Meaning
bridi a claim; a complete Lojban sentence
selbri the relationship word in a bridi (the "verb")
sumti a participant in the relationship (the "nouns")
gismu root word, always 5 letters (e.g. prami)
cmavo grammar word, short (e.g. mi, do)

Summary

You learned the shape of a Lojban sentence: sumti + selbri + sumti = bridi. You built sentences with mi, do, and ti as sumti, and gismu as selbri. You can now say things like mi tavla do (I talk to you) and mi citka ti (I eat this).

Tomorrow preview: You'll add a second sumti to more verbs and discover that each gismu has a fixed place structure — tavla isn't just "talk," it's "x1 talks to x2 about x3 in language x4."
